module.p: cèile spouse, consort, mate, wife, husband; counterpart, fellow is a masculine common noun, with plural form cèilean.

The basic use of cèile is as a (sex-neutral) interpersonal relationship noun, usually occurring with a possessive determiner as pre-specifier –
Seo mo chèile. This is my husband/wife.

Note the following compounds –
bràthair mo chèile my brother-in-law
piuthar do chèile your sister-in-law
màthair a chèile his mother-in-law
athair a cèile her father-in-law

As well as the more innovative, English-flavoured alternatives –
mo bhràthair cèile my brother-in-law
do phiuthar chèile your sister-in-law
a mhàthair chèile his mother-in-law
a h-athair cèile her father-in-law
cf. cèile mo bhràthar &c?

a chèile each other, one another functions like a (fossilised?) reciprocal pronoun –
Phòg iad a chèile. They kissed each other.
Bha sinn a’ bruidhinn ri (a) chèile. We were talking to each other.

Note the lack of explicit agreement in modern Gaelic –
phòg iad an cèile
bha sinn a’ bruidhinn ri ar cèile

li.gd: Bha iad a’ pògadh a chèile.
Cha robh iad pòsta aig a chèile.
li.tr: They weren’t married to each other.

li.gd: ... ’s iad a’ leughadh aodann a chèile ...

module.p:
Also: càch a chèile –
Cha robh iad a’ bruidhinn ri càch a chèile.
They weren’t speaking to each other. td. 130
na bòidean a thug iad do chàch a chèile
the vows that they had given to each other td. 130
Biodh gràdh agaibh do chàch a chèile.
[You should] love one another. td. 130

Note also the following idioms –
tha na bràithrean thar a chèile the brothers are at loggerheads / have fallen out with each other
tha sinn mòr aig a chèile we are good friends (with each other)

li.gd: Faodaidh mise an taigh a rannsachadh agus a h-uile càil a tha na bhroinn a thoirt às a chèile.
li.tr: I can search the house and take apart everything that is in it.

module.p:
às (or an) dèidh a chèile after each other, successive, in succession [2004 Colin Mark Am Faclair Gàidhlig-Beurla td. 130]
Thàinig iad a-steach às dèidh a chèile.
They entered one after the other / in succession. td. 130

Non-idiomatic uses
Ach nuair a chuala iad mo sgeulachd, mhothaich mi gun tug iad sùil air a chèile.
But when they heard my story, I noticed that they glanced at each other. td. 15
Cha bhi sinn a’ sgreuchail ri chèile idir, no a’ sadadh nan soithichean air a chèile.
We don’t scream at eah other at all, nor throw dishes at each other. td. 104

Non-idiomatic uses
Na leugh thu Lebhiticus XX:21 agus Deuteronomi XXV:5? Nach eil iad calg-dhìreach an aghaidh a chèile?
Have you not reas Leviticus 20:21 and Deutoronomy 25:5? Are they not diametrically opposed to each other? td. 6

Non-idiomatic uses
Chan aithnich thu bho chèile iad [ie. dà dhual].
You can’t tell them [two locks of hair] apart. td. 43

p.en: from each other / from one another

module.p:
Non-idiomatic uses
Choinnich e ri Elsie May aon oidhche ann an taigh-seinnse anns a’ bhaile mhòr, agus shaoil sinn gun deach an dithis a dhèanamh dha a chèile.
He met Elsie May one night in a bar in the city, and we thought that the two of them were made for each other. td. 26

Non-idiomatic uses
Cha robh i ga choimhead ach uair no dhà sa bhliadhna. Ach bha iad a’ sgrìobhadh gu chèile a h-uile seachdain.
She only saw him once or twice a year. But they wrote to each other every week. td. 43

li.gd: Cha robh na pàirtean a’ tighinn gu chèile.
Bha iomadh rud gan tarraing gu chèile.
li.tr: Many things attracted them to each other.

module.p:
le chèile all, both, jointly, together is a quasi-manner adverbial –
[subject-modifying] Chaidh iad le chèile a Lunnainn. They both/all went to London.
Bha sgrìobhadh eile ann a’ moladh an dithis [ie. Mgr. Coull agus a bhean Laura] agus ag innse gur ann an Innse Gall a rugadh iad le chèile.
There was another note praising the two of them [Mr Coull and his wife Laura] and saying that they had both been born in the Hebrides. td. 86
Dh’fhalbh iad le chèile.
They left together. / They both left. td. 241
Chaidh an triùir le chèile don mhuileann.
The three went together to the mill td. 130
Chaidh Uisdean a chur dhachaigh air itealan-eiridinn agus chuir an t-ospadal Sandaidh còmhla ris airson coimhead às a dhèidh. Bha iad le chèile glè dheònach sin a dhèanamh, oir bha iad ann am fiachan thall ’s a-bhos.
Hugh was sent home on an emergency plane and the hospital sent Sandy with him to look after him. They were both very willing to do that, because they were in debt(s) all over the place. td. 58
Tha na leabhraichean seo le chèile nan cruinneachadh bàrdachd.
These books are both collections of poetry. td. 130 The subject is inanimate here.
[predicate modifying] Tha clann againn le chèile. We all/both have children.
’S e cànanan Cèilteach a tha annta le chèile.
They are both Celtic languages. td. 130
Tha earbaill dhosrach orra le chèile.
They both have bushy tails. td. 130
[object modifying] Phòg i na balaich le chèile. ?? She kissed all/both the boys.
[indirect object modifying] Thug e leabhar dhaibh le chèile. He gave them all/both a book.
Thug e orra le chèile de chofaidh làidir òl.
He made them both drink strong coffee. td. 130
Thug e pòg dhaibh le chèile.
He gave them both a kiss. td. 130
[emphasising conjunction] Tha Màiri agus Raonaid le chèile pòsta. Mary and Rachel are both married.
Ach bha peatan aige [ie. aig an tidsear] cuideachd, balaich agus clann-nighean le chèile.
But he [the teacher] had favourites too, boys and girls both. td. 69
Thusa agus mise le chèile.
Both you and I. td. 130
cf. both, all.

Non-idiomatic uses
Ceann sreath bha cùirt ann agus thàinig a h-uile càil a-mach an sin. Lorg iad an Glaschu mar a choinnich Syd agus Harry ri chèile agus gu robh deagh fhios aig Syd gur e Harry a thruaill a leanabh.
In due course there was a trial and everything came out there. They found out in Glasgow how Syd and Harry had met each other and that Syd knew well that it was Harry who had violated his child. td. 62
Ann an cumadh cha robh iad coltach ri chèile idir. Bha Sandaidh meadhanach àrd, caol, le falt dubh agus aghaidh dhorch, bhiorach, ach bha Uisdean beag, le falt bàn is sùilean gorma, neo-chiontach.
In appearance they were not like each other at all. Sandy was of average height, think, with black hair and a dark, pointed face, but Hugh was short, with fair hair and innocent, blue eyes. td. 52

li.gd: Bha iad a’ tighinn ri chèile gu dòigheil.
li.tr: They were getting on together handsomely.

p.en: put together, assemble, build, compile, collate, amalgamate, cement, compose, construct, fabricate, join, juxtapose

li.gd: Tha e dìreach an dèidh Gràmair Gàidhlig a chur ri chèile.
li.tr: He has just compiled a Gaelic Grammar.

li.gd: Bidh seo gan cumail ri chèile.
Tha an taigh againne agus taigh Eilidh, nighean mo pheathar, ri taobh a chèile.
li.tr: Our house and my niece Helen’s house were next to each other.

li.gd: Bha iad a’ coiseachd ri taobh a chèile.
li.tr: They were walking side by side / abreast.

module.p:
tro chèile confused, agitated, tangled, untidy, disordered, muddled, in turmoil has adjectival force –
[noun modifier] duine tro chèile ?? a confused person
anns na bliadhnachan tro-chèile an dèidh a’ chogaidh
in the confused years after the war td. 599
bi tro chèile be confused/agitated &c.
Bha cargu aig an Langitoto airson Launceston an Tasmania agus ràinig Syd am port sin gun leigeil ris do dhuine air bòrd cho troimh-chèile ’s a bha e.
There was cargo on the Langitoto for Launceston in Tasmania and Syd arrived at that port without betraying to the men on board how agitated he was. td. 60
Bha m’ inntinn cho tro-chèile ’s nach do dh’fhan mi ris a’ bhus.
My mind was so confused that I didn’t wait for the bus. td. 599
rach tro chèile get confused/agitated &c.
B’ fheudar do Eilidh seo eadar-theangachadh do Newall agus thòisich e ga ceasnachadh mar fhear-lagha. Chaidh e cho troimh- chèile ’s gun tuirt i ris, [...]
Helen had to translate this for Newall and he started t interrogate her like a lawyer. He got so agitated that she said to him [...] td. 80
cuir tro chèile confuse, complicate, agitate, disconcert, muddle, jumble
Tha mi ag innse seo dhut gus an tuig thu cho cudromach ’s a tha e seo a chumail dìomhair. Tha e glè fhurasta Màsasmo a chur troimh-chèile, agus ’s ann òirnne a chuireadh e a’ choire.
I am telling you this so that you understand how important it is to keep this a secret. It is very easy to confuse Masasma, and it is us that he would blame. td. 20
Bha iad air an cur tro-chèile.
They were confused. td. 599

cf. The (exocentric) compound noun tro-chèile fem. agitation, confusion, dementia, disorder, ferment, muddle, tangle, turmoil, welter [2004 Colin Mark Am Faclair Gàidhlig-Beurla td. 599]. Also: tro-chèile inntinn(e) psychosis; cur-tro-chèile upset.
